reviewText: Casual Beatles fans may wanna skip this one. It's basically a bunch of clips of them going from place to place facing screaming fans and the like, along with a handful of interviews. Nothing earth shattering.But there are a few intriguing moments. There is a clip of Pete Best (original drummer) trying to maintain his dignity during an appearance on "I've Got a Secret." Reactions and fallout from John Lennon's infamous statement about the Beatles and Jesus (the statements from KKK leader Bobby Shelton are almost incomprehensible) and the near arrest of the Bay-tels at a Minneapolis motel. The clip of our guys in the Shakespearian skit is a bit had to follow with the screaming crowd. Not much here to write home about. But it's interesting to watch at least once or twice.
Title: N/A

reviewText: FUN WITH THE FAB FOUR is another of the many Beatles "documentaries" that consist of press conference excerpts, interview clips, an overabundance of screeching Beatlemaniacs and the occasional TV broadcast dub. Televison samples include their Midsummer's Night Dream sketch.The primary drawbacks of this GOODTIMES VHS is a slow running speed, which makes already degraded source material that much the blurrier. For a low-priced peek however, you'll find it most adequate. If absolutely necessary to your Beatles archive, this hour-length melange is available on equally-inexpensiveDVDs.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If your idea of an ideal hour with the Beatles is an unstructured collection of clips with bad audio and without a single note of Beatles music, then you're going to absolutely adore this DVD. I repeat - this DVD does not contain any Beatles music at all. Instead, there's a lot of raw footage of Beatles interviews and TV appearances, some of which have non-synchronized sound. This is the same exact collection that's been floating around since GoodTimes video unleashed this upon the budget VHS market back in the late 1980s.I'm giving this two stars rather than one because a couple of the segments might be interesting to Beatles fans. There's a Shakespearian spoof from the same British TV special that can see musical excerpts from in the Anthology series, as well as a rare American TV appearance by Pete Best on a game show. Of course, both clips are presented without any supporting context, but they're nice to see regardless if you're especially into the British Invasion-era Beatles period.It's stunning to me that the product description does not mention that this is a music-free video. It's equally stunning that a high-quality Beatles film like "The Compleat Beatles" - which has many of the same clips as the ones in this one, albeit with structure and context - has NEVER received a legit DVD release whereas "Fun with the Fab Four" has.Buyer beware.
summary: This is still in print after Anthology?!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I, for one, get a kick out of the irony of some of these Beatles DVD titles.  "Beatles Celebration," for instance.  That film did not celebrate the Beatles at all.  Then there was "The Legend Continues," which was just another rehash of previously seen footage, only "continuing" to get some quick cash out of unsuspecting Beatles fans.  Now there's "Fun With The Fab Four," which truthfully isn't fun at all.I purchased this DVD back to back with the "Beatles Unauthorized" film, and after viewing them both, I must say that this one is far more disappointing.  The footage is not in the best quality and can usually be seen elsewhere in far clearer picture and sound.  Often times, one clip cuts to another, with the first clip's audio still playing underneath.  Then it cuts back.  I find this type of editing to be very annoying.  There are a few moments I enjoyed, but overall it is cheap garbage.  I would, however, recommend the "Beatles Unauthorized" DVD - at least that one has some concert footage, and the editing isn't as jumpy.
Title: N/A
